moves.1. e4: Keres opens with P-K4, an opening that usually leads to a fast-moving, tactical game.
moves.1... c6: Arlamowski intends to play a Caro-Kann in response.
moves.2. Nc3: Instead of playing P-Q4 at once, Keres decides to develop his QN.
moves.2... d5: Arlamowski ignores the unusual move order and plays his intended second move.
moves.3. Nf3: Keres decides against 3 P-Q4, which would transpose into the 3 N-QB3 variation of the Caro-Kann, and develops his other Knight.
moves.3... dxe4: Arlamowski initiates an exchange of central Pawns...
moves.4... Nf6: With Keres having 2 pieces already developed, Arlamowski decides he'd better start developing his own.
moves.5... Nbd7: ...which Arlamowski unaccountably falls directly into. He failed to ask the question: why would Keres block his own KB with a seemingly useless Queen move?
moves.6. Nd6#: That's why! Nicely done by Keres, with help from his oblivious opponent.
